text: The highest temperature ever officially recorded on Earth was 56.7°C (134.1°F) at Furnace Creek in Death Valley, California, on July 10, 1913, though this measurement is contested by some meteorologists.
The lowest temperature ever recorded on Earth was -89.2°C (-128.6°F) at Vostok Station, Antarctica, on July 21, 1983.
The greatest temperature change in two minutes was 27°C (49°F), from -20°C to 7°C, recorded in Spearfish, South Dakota on January 22, 1943.
Verkhoyansk, Russia, has the largest temperature range ever recorded in one location: 105.8°C (190.4°F), spanning from -67.8°C in winter to 38.0°C in summer.
The highest dew point temperature ever recorded was 35°C (95°F) at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, on July 8, 2003, resulting in a heat index of 81.1°C (178°F).
Qurayyat, Oman, recorded the highest minimum temperature for a 24-hour period at 42.6°C (108.7°F) on June 25, 2018—meaning it never got cooler than that all day.
The Lut Desert in Iran recorded the highest natural ground surface temperature ever measured by satellite: 70.7°C (159.3°F) in 2005.
The most rainfall in one minute was 38 mm (1.5 inches) at Barot, Guadeloupe, on November 26, 1970.
Cilaos on Réunion Island received 1,825 mm (71.9 inches) of rain in 24 hours during Tropical Cyclone Denise in January 1966—the world record for a single day.
Cherrapunji, India, received the most rainfall in one year: 26,470 mm (1,042 inches) from 1860 to 1861.
Quillagua, Chile, is the driest place on Earth, receiving less than 0.2 mm of rainfall per year—less than an eyelash width.
Oahu, Hawaii, experienced 331 consecutive days with measurable rainfall in 1939-1940, the world record for continuous rain.
The deepest snowfall ever recorded was 11.82 meters (38.8 feet) on Mount Ibuki, Japan, on February 14, 1927.
Mount Baker, Washington, received 29.0 meters (95 feet) of snow in a single season (1998-1999), the world record for seasonal snowfall.
Marble Bar, Australia, experienced 160 consecutive days above 37.8°C (100°F) from October 1923 to April 1924.
The fastest non-tornadic wind speed ever recorded was 408 km/h (254 mph) during Severe Tropical Cyclone Olivia on Barrow Island, Australia, on April 10, 1996.
The fastest wind speed in a tornado was calculated at 516.6 km/h (321 mph) during the 1999 Bridge Creek-Moore tornado in Oklahoma.
The heaviest hailstone officially recorded weighed 1.02 kg (2.25 pounds) and fell in Gopalganj District, Bangladesh, on April 14, 1986.
The largest hailstone by diameter was 20 cm (8 inches) and fell in Vivian, South Dakota, on July 23, 2010.
The longest lightning bolt ever recorded stretched 829 km (515 miles) across Texas and Oklahoma on October 22, 2017.
The longest-duration single lightning flash lasted 17.1 seconds over Uruguay and Argentina on June 18, 2020.

The highest UV index ever measured was 43.3 at Bolivia's Licancabur volcano at 5,920 meters elevation on December 29, 2003—light-skinned individuals could experience moderate sunburn in as little as 4 minutes.
Typhoon Tip in 1979 was the most intense tropical cyclone ever recorded, with a central pressure of 870 hPa and sustained winds of 305 km/h (190 mph).
Hurricane Patricia in 2015 had the highest maximum sustained wind speed ever recorded in a tropical cyclone at 345 km/h (215 mph).
The 2011 Super Outbreak produced 207 confirmed tornadoes in a single 24-hour period on April 27, 2011, including 4 rated EF5.
The deadliest tornado in history killed approximately 1,300 people in Manikganj District, Bangladesh, on April 26, 1989.
The Tri-State Tornado of 1925 traveled 219 miles (352 km) continuously on the ground across Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana, killing 695 people.
The highest air pressure ever recorded above 750 meters was 1084.8 hPa at Tosontsengel, Mongolia, on December 19, 2001.
July 22, 2024, was the warmest day on record for the entire planet, with a global average temperature of 17.16°C (62.89°F).
Lightning heats the air around it to approximately 30,000°C (54,000°F)—about five times hotter than the surface of the Sun.
Lightning occurs on Earth approximately 44 times per second, equating to nearly 1.4 billion flashes per year.
About 70% of all lightning occurs over land in the tropics, where atmospheric convection is greatest.
An average bolt of negative lightning carries 30,000 amperes, transfers 15 coulombs of charge, and releases 1 gigajoule of energy.
Positive lightning, which makes up less than 5% of all strikes, can produce peak currents up to 400,000 amperes—more than 10 times stronger than typical negative lightning.
Lake Maracaibo in Venezuela is the most lightning-prone place on Earth, averaging 250 lightning bolts per day and seeing lightning on 297 days per year.
The village of Kifuka in the Democratic Republic of Congo receives 158 lightning strikes per square kilometer per year, one of the highest densities in the world.
Most negative cloud-to-ground lightning flashes consist of 3-4 individual strokes, though some can have as many as 30 strokes in rapid succession.
The return stroke of lightning travels at up to one-third the speed of light—approximately 100,000 km/s.
Only about 25% of all lightning is cloud-to-ground; 75% occurs within clouds or between clouds.
Lightning can travel through a typical cloud-to-ground channel exceeding 5 km (3.1 miles) in length.
The Apollo 12 rocket was struck by lightning shortly after takeoff because the rocket's exhaust plume created a conductive pathway through the atmosphere.
Thermonuclear explosions can trigger lightning within the mushroom cloud due to intense gamma radiation creating charged regions through Compton scattering.
The median duration of a lightning flash is 0.52 seconds, composed of multiple strokes lasting 60-70 microseconds each.
Ship contrails in the ocean have been found to slightly influence lightning frequency, as the water vapor from ships can affect the atmosphere's electrical conductivity.
The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs where temperatures range from -15°C to -25°C and contains a mixture of supercooled water droplets, ice crystals, and graupel.
About 90% of lightning leader 'steps' are approximately 45 meters (148 feet) in length as the channel ionizes its way through the atmosphere.
Lightning is considered an Essential Climate Variable by the World Meteorological Organization due to its connections to storm intensity and climate patterns.

Ball lightning, described as luminous spheres from pea-sized to several meters in diameter, has been reported for centuries but was first scientifically recorded with video and spectrum analysis in 2012 on the Tibetan Plateau.
A 1960 survey at Oak Ridge National Laboratory found that 5.6% of personnel reported having witnessed ball lightning, suggesting it may be more common than previously thought.

In 1753, Professor Georg Richmann of Saint Petersburg was killed by ball lightning while conducting a kite experiment similar to Benjamin Franklin's—the first recorded scientific fatality from ball lightning.
Scottish physicist C.T.R. Wilson predicted in the 1920s that electrical breakdown should occur high above thunderstorms—sprites weren't visually confirmed until 1989.
Sprites are massive electrical discharges that occur 50-90 km above thunderstorms, colored reddish-orange, and were named after Shakespeare's mischievous spirits.
Blue jets emanate upward from cloud tops at speeds of 100-140 km/s and can extend up to 50 km altitude, lasting only 200-300 milliseconds.
Gigantic jets can travel from thunderstorm tops to 90 km altitude, with one observed in 2001 reaching speeds of at least 2,000 km/s as it spread into the ionosphere.
ELVES (Emission of Light and Very Low Frequency perturbations) are flattened, expanding glows around 400 km in diameter that last only about one millisecond in the ionosphere above thunderstorms.
Transient luminous events have been observed on Jupiter by the NASA Juno probe, proving that upper-atmospheric lightning phenomena occur on other planets.
The global rate of transient luminous events is estimated at several million per year, based on FORMOSAT-2 satellite observations.
TROLLs (Transient Red Optical Luminous Lineaments) are red streaks that form after strong sprites and were only recently classified as a distinct phenomenon.
Ghosts (Greenish Optical Emissions from Sprite Tops) appear as faint green glows that persist after a red sprite dissipates, and were first noted as distinct phenomena in 2019.
Earth has experienced at least five major ice ages: the Huronian (2.4 billion years ago), Cryogenian, Andean-Saharan, late Paleozoic, and the current Quaternary Ice Age.
The Huronian glaciation 2.4-2.1 billion years ago was caused by the Great Oxygenation Event, which eliminated atmospheric methane, a powerful greenhouse gas.
During the Cryogenian period 720-630 million years ago, Earth may have become a 'Snowball Earth' with glacial ice sheets reaching the equator.
The term 'ice age' was coined by Karl Friedrich Schimper in 1837, who noticed moss growing on erratic boulders and deduced that glaciers once covered much of Europe.
The Antarctic ice sheet began forming about 34 million years ago, while the Arctic ice cap didn't form until about 2.58 million years ago.
The current interglacial period (the Holocene) began about 11,700 years ago, and without human influence, the next glacial period would likely begin at least 50,000 years from now.
Anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions may outweigh the orbital forcing of Milankovitch cycles for hundreds of thousands of years, potentially preventing the next ice age.
The closing of the Isthmus of Panama about 3 million years ago may have triggered strong glaciation in North America by changing ocean circulation patterns.
During glacial periods, Earth's ice sheets increase the planet's albedo (reflectivity), while forests decrease it—this creates a positive feedback loop that intensifies cooling.
When glaciers grind rocks into dust and wind transports iron-rich dust to the open ocean, it fertilizes massive algal blooms that pull CO2 from the atmosphere, intensifying ice ages.
The Himalayas may be a major factor in the current ice age because their uplift increased rainfall and the rate at which CO2 is washed from the atmosphere through weathering.
During the last glacial period, sea levels fluctuated 20-30 meters as water was sequestered in ice sheets, periodically opening and closing the Bering Strait.
An ice-free Arctic Ocean paradoxically leads to more snowfall at high latitudes because more water evaporates, potentially triggering glacial advances.
The existence of the greenhouse effect was proposed by Joseph Fourier in 1824, before the term 'greenhouse effect' was coined by Nils Ekholm in 1901.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Eunice Newton Foote was the first to demonstrate CO2's heat-capturing effect in 1856, three years before John Tyndall's more famous experiments.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Svante Arrhenius calculated in 1896 that doubling atmospheric CO2 would increase global temperatures by 5-6°C, remarkably close to modern estimates.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Arrhenius initially believed CO2-induced warming would take thousands of years, but by 1908 revised his estimate to hundreds of years due to increasing fuel consumption.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Chinese scholar Shen Kuo proposed gradual climate change in 1088 AD after discovering petrified bamboo fossils in the dry northern regions of China, far from where bamboo typically grows.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Milutin Milankovitch improved calculations of Earth's orbital variations that James Croll had begun, predicting ice age cycles of about 21,000 years.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: The first weather map was produced in 1820 by Heinrich Wilhelm Brandes, who plotted past weather observations on maps to understand storm patterns.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Hans Suess's carbon-14 analysis in 1955 proved that CO2 from fossil fuels was not immediately absorbed by the ocean, disproving a major skeptic argument.
source_name: Wikipedia - History of Climate Change Science

text: Tropical cyclones require sea surface temperatures of at least 26-27°C (79-81°F) to form and maintain their strength.
Tropical cyclones rarely form within 5° of the equator because the Coriolis effect is too weak to create rotation at those latitudes.
On average, 80-90 named tropical cyclones form each year worldwide, with over half developing hurricane-force winds of 120 km/h or more.
South Atlantic tropical cyclones are extremely rare because of consistently strong wind shear and a weak Intertropical Convergence Zone.
Climate change increased Hurricane Harvey's rainfall by 7-38%, Hurricane Ian's by 18%, and increased peak wind speeds in all eleven 2024 Atlantic hurricanes.
When hurricane wind speeds rise by 5%, destructive power increases by about 50%, so climate change's 11% increase to Hurricane Helene's winds more than doubled its destruction.
Tropical cyclones can be between 100 and 2,000 km in diameter—Typhoon Tip in 1979 spanned about 2,200 km, nearly half the width of the continental United States.
May is the least active month for tropical cyclones globally, while September is the most active, and November is the only month when all tropical cyclone basins are in season.
Category 5 hurricanes have become much more common in recent decades, with the 20-year average of Category 4 and 5 Atlantic hurricanes approximately doubling since 2000.
A tropical cyclone's passage causes substantial ocean cooling through upwelling, which can drop sea surface temperatures enough to inhibit the next storm's development.
Small tropical cyclones are more prone to rapid intensification than larger ones, which makes them particularly dangerous because they're harder to forecast.
Tornadoes occur on every continent except Antarctica, with the United States experiencing by far the most tornadoes of any country.
The widest tornado on record was approximately 2.6 miles (4.2 km) across during the 2013 El Reno, Oklahoma tornado.
One tornado was reported to have a damage path only 7 feet (2.1 meters) long—among the shortest ever recorded.
Approximately 1% of tornadoes rotate anticyclonically (clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere), usually forming on the anticyclonic side of a supercell's rear flank downdraft.
Tornadoes can take on the color of the debris they pick up—Great Plains tornadoes often appear red due to the soil color, while those crossing snow appear white.
There is mounting evidence that most tornadoes have a clear, calm center with extremely low pressure, similar to the eye of a tropical cyclone.
On June 24, 2003, a probe near Manchester, South Dakota, measured a 100-millibar pressure drop as a violent tornado passed over it.
Tornadoes produce detectable infrasonic signatures and seismic signals, leading to ongoing research on using these for prediction systems.
In the US, the average tornado travels 5 miles (8 km) on the ground and is about 500 feet (150 m) across.
Most extreme tornadoes can attain wind speeds exceeding 480 km/h (300 mph) and stay on the ground for more than 100 km.
The term 'tornado' comes from the Spanish 'tronada' (thunderstorm), with the spelling influenced by 'tornar' (to twist or turn).
Intense forest fires like the 2019-20 Australian bushfires can create their own weather systems called pyrocumulonimbus that produce 'fire lightning' and fire tornadoes.
The first daily weather forecasts were published in The Times on August 1, 1861, by Robert FitzRoy, who also coined the term 'weather forecast.'
Before the electric telegraph in 1835, weather reports could only travel about 60-160 km per day, making forecasting impossible.
In 350 BC, Aristotle wrote 'Meteorologica,' the first systematic work on weather, which gave us the term 'meteorology' from the Greek 'meteoros' meaning 'high in the sky.'
Lewis Fry Richardson's 1922 book on numerical weather prediction envisioned a 'forecast factory' with thousands of people performing calculations by hand.
The first computerized weather forecast was performed in 1950 by a team including John von Neumann using the ENIAC computer.
The world's first televised weather forecasts were experimentally broadcast by the BBC in November 1936.
The US spent approximately $5.8 billion on weather forecasting in 2009, producing benefits estimated at six times that amount.
Luke Howard developed the cloud classification system in 1802 using Latin names, which became the basis of the international system still used today.
The German poet Goethe was so impressed by Luke Howard's cloud classification that he composed four poems dedicated to Howard.
Clouds are the main uncertainty in climate sensitivity calculations, making them crucial for understanding how much the Earth will warm.
The word 'cloud' originally meant 'hill' or 'mass of rock' in Old English; it became metaphorically associated with rain clouds around the 13th century.
High clouds form at altitudes up to 18,300 m (60,000 ft) in the tropics, 12,200 m (40,000 ft) in temperate regions, and 7,600 m (25,000 ft) in polar regions.
Cumulonimbus clouds can penetrate the tropopause and push into the stratosphere during intense convection.
Nephology, the science of clouds, gets its name from the Greek 'nephos' meaning cloud—not to be confused with nephrology, the study of kidneys.
Clouds have been observed on other planets containing methane, ammonia, and sulfuric acid instead of water.
A microclimate in the Gstettneralm Sinkhole in Austria recorded a temperature of -53°C (-63°F) due to cold air pooling.
San Francisco can have temperature differences of up to 30°F (17°C) between the foggy coastal areas and the downtown heat island just miles apart.
The Big Island of Hawaii has microclimates so extreme that Kailua-Kona receives 18 inches of rain per year while Hilo, just 60 miles away, receives 127 inches.
Tree ferns thrive at the Lost Gardens of Heligan in Cornwall, England (latitude 50°N) due to a protected microclimate in a sheltered dell.
If forests didn't create their own water cycle through evapotranspiration, there would be no forest far from coastlines because rainfall would decline too much inland.
The term 'microclimate' first appeared in publications in the 1950s, including the book 'Climates in Miniature' by Thomas Bedford Franklin.
Gran Canaria is called the 'Miniature Continent' for its rich variety of microclimates within a small area.
The Ticino region of Switzerland has a microclimate warm enough for palm trees and banana trees to grow.
The water vapor feedback effectively doubles the warming that would otherwise occur from CO2 increases alone.
The Planck response—how thermal radiation increases as objects warm—is the most fundamental feedback in the climate system and prevents runaway warming.
The lapse rate feedback is a negative feedback globally but becomes positive in polar regions, contributing significantly to Arctic amplification.
Arctic sea ice decline between 1979 and 2011 was responsible for radiative forcing equivalent to a quarter of all CO2 emissions during the same period.
The Arctic has warmed nearly four times faster than the global average since 1979, largely due to ice-albedo feedback.
East Antarctica has experienced very little net warming over seven decades because its ice sheet rises nearly 4 km above sea level, maintaining high stability.
Cloud feedback has the largest uncertainty of any climate feedback, with a confidence interval from -0.10 to 0.94 W/m²·K.
The carbon cycle absorbs more than half of CO2 emissions every year into plants and the ocean, but this percentage will decrease as carbon sinks become saturated.
Total loss of Arctic summer sea ice would increase regional temperatures by over 1.5°C while adding about 0.19°C to global average temperatures.
The El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a self-sustaining climate oscillation that occurs every 2-7 years, with El Niño lasting 9 months to 2 years.
The Madden-Julian Oscillation is an eastward-moving pattern of increased tropical rainfall with a period of 30-60 days, primarily over the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
The Quasi-biennial Oscillation causes dominant stratospheric winds around the equator to switch from easterly to westerly and back every 28 months.
The Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation has a period of 55-70 years and affects hurricane frequency and intensity, rainfall, and droughts.
Dansgaard-Oeschger cycles are rapid warming events occurring roughly every 1,500 years during ice ages, with temperature changes of up to 10°C within decades.
The 1815 eruption of Mount Tambora caused the 'Year Without a Summer' in 1816, leading to crop failures, famines, and disease outbreaks worldwide.
The 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo lowered global temperatures by about 0.5°C for up to three years due to sulfuric acid aerosols in the stratosphere.
The Chicxulub asteroid impact 66 million years ago caused global temperatures to drop by up to 26°C and produced sub-freezing temperatures for 3-16 years.
Three to four billion years ago, the Sun emitted only 75% as much power as today, yet liquid water existed on Earth—this is called the 'faint young Sun paradox.'
Glaciation 2.3 billion years ago was triggered by the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis, which depleted CO2 and introduced free oxygen to the atmosphere.
Global cooling over the past 40 million years has been driven partly by the expansion of grass-grazer ecosystems.
US Geological Survey estimates that volcanic emissions of CO2 are 100-300 times less than human emissions annually.
The highest temperature north of the Arctic Circle was 38.0°C (100.4°F) recorded at Verkhoyansk, Russia, on June 20, 2020.
Lytton, British Columbia, reached 49.6°C (121.3°F) on June 29, 2021—the highest temperature ever recorded north of 50°N latitude.
The fastest temperature drop in 2 minutes was 15°C (27°F) at Sydney Airport, Australia, on January 23, 2010, falling from 41°C to 26°C.
The coldest summer temperature ever recorded was -33°C (-27.4°F) at Summit Camp, Greenland, on July 4, 2017.
The coldest temperature ever recorded in the tropics was -25.2°C (-13.4°F) at Mazocruz, Peru, on June 30, 1966.
Imperial, California, experienced the highest temperature ever recorded during rain: 48.3°C (118.9°F) on July 24, 2018.
The highest temperature at 100% relative humidity was 34°C (93°F) at Jask, Iran, on July 21, 2012.
Cyclone Hyacinthe dumped 6,433 mm (253.3 inches) of rain on Réunion Island in January 1980—the most precipitation from a single tropical cyclone.
Port Martin, Antarctica, experienced the fastest daily average wind speed: 174 km/h (108 mph) on March 21-22, 1951.
The 1974 Super Outbreak produced 7 F5 tornadoes in a single outbreak—the most F5 tornadoes in recorded history.
A supercell near Nueva Rosita, Mexico, on May 24, 2016, reached 68,000 feet (21 km)—the tallest non-tropical thunderstorm ever confirmed.
The Labor Day Hurricane of 1935 made landfall in Florida with the lowest pressure ever recorded on US land: 892 hPa (26.35 inHg).
Death Valley holds the record for most consecutive days above 48.9°C (120°F): 40 days from July 9 to August 17, 1917.
Death Valley holds the highest average monthly temperature record: 42.5°C (108.5°F) in July 2024.
Cherrapunji, India, received 2,493 mm (98.1 inches) of rain in just 48 hours on June 15-16, 1995.
Cyclone Gamede dropped 3,929 mm (154.7 inches) of rain on Réunion Island in 72 hours in February 2007.
Mawsynram, India, holds the highest average annual rainfall: 11,872 mm (467.4 inches) over 38 years of observations.
Tamarack, California, received 9.91 meters (390 inches) of snow in January 1911 alone, leading to a snow depth of 11.46 meters (451 inches) by March.
Mount Rainier, Washington, received 31.5 meters (102 feet) of snow in a single year, from February 1971 to February 1972.
Snow fell as far south as Tampico, Mexico (22°N latitude) in February 1895 during the Great Freeze—the lowest latitude sea-level snow in North American history.
Mount Washington, New Hampshire, recorded the fastest non-cyclonic wind: 372 km/h (231 mph) on April 12, 1934.
The first gale warning service began in February 1861 when Robert FitzRoy used telegraph communications to warn ships of approaching storms.
Francis Ronalds invented the first photographic weather recording instruments in 1845, including a barograph that FitzRoy later used for forecasting.
The International Cloud Atlas, first published in 1896, standardized cloud vocabulary and classification worldwide.
In 904 AD, Ibn Wahshiyya's Nabatean Agriculture discussed weather forecasting based on lunar phases, planetary positions, and wind movements.
Chinese weather prediction methods extend at least as far back as 300 BC, around the same time as ancient Indian weather-prediction methods.
Weather forecasting is so chaotic that time steps for global models are measured in tens of minutes, while regional models use time steps of 1-4 minutes.
The sinking of the Royal Charter in October 1859, killing over 450 people, directly motivated Robert FitzRoy to establish modern weather forecasting.
The Beaufort Wind Scale was developed by Francis Beaufort, who also helped establish 200 weather recording stations at British coast guard stations.
Practical numerical weather prediction didn't begin until 1955 because earlier attempts failed due to the enormous computational requirements.
Weather drones are being developed to fill the observational gap between 100 meters and 6 km above ground level, where traditional sensors are limited.
The first weather radio broadcast in the US was made in 1925 by Edward B. Rideout on WEEI, the Edison Electric Illuminating station in Boston.
The European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts model runs predictions 10 days into the future, while the Global Forecast System runs 16 days ahead.
Klara Dan von Neumann was one of the ENIAC programmers who helped produce the first computerized weather forecast in 1950.
Ball lightning typically has a diameter of 10-20 cm (4-8 inches), lasts 1 second to over a minute, and often leaves behind an odor of sulfur.
The earliest known reference to ball lightning dates to 1195, when monk Gervase of Canterbury described a 'marvellous sign' of a spherical fiery object near London.
The Great Thunderstorm at Widecombe-in-the-Moor church in 1638 killed 4 people when an 8-foot ball of fire reportedly struck and entered the church.
Tsar Nicholas II reported witnessing ball lightning as a child during a church service, watching a fiery ball fly near his grandfather Alexander II.
Nikola Tesla reportedly could artificially produce 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) ball lightning in laboratory demonstrations.
Submariners in World War II reported frequent ball lightning when battery banks were switched, due to the highly inductive electrical motors.
The 2014 scientific recording of natural ball lightning on the Tibetan Plateau detected silicon, calcium, iron, nitrogen, and oxygen in its emission spectrum.
Ball lightning has been reported passing through closed windows, solid walls, and even flying through aircraft cabins without causing damage.
In 1749, Admiral Chambers reported seeing a ball of blue fire appear 3 miles from HMS Montague, approach the ship, and explode 'as great as if a hundred cannons had been discharged.'
A ball lightning in 1977 entered the Golden Temple at Amritsar, India, and exited through a side door—the incident is inscribed on the temple's front wall.
Loganair Flight 6780 in 2014 experienced ball lightning in the forward cabin just before a nose lightning strike, causing confusion that nearly crashed the plane.
World War II pilots reported mysterious glowing balls following their aircraft, called 'foo fighters'—ball lightning has been suggested as one explanation.
Laura Ingalls Wilder described ball lightning in her books: three balls appearing during a blizzard near a cast-iron stove, which her mother chased with a broom.
Occultist Aleister Crowley reported witnessing ball lightning at Lake Pasquaney in 1916, describing it as 'dazzling' before it exploded near his knee.
The natural ball lightning recorded in 2012 traveled at 8.6 m/s, had a diameter of 5 meters, and showed oscillations at 100 Hz possibly from nearby power lines.
Air within clouds becomes saturated when cooled to its dew point, forming cloud droplets on condensation nuclei like salt or dust particles.
Jean-Baptiste Lamarck proposed a French cloud classification system in 1802, but it failed because it used informal French names instead of universal Latin.
Noctilucent clouds form at 'extreme level' in the mesosphere, while nacreous (mother-of-pearl) clouds form in the stratosphere.
Low clouds can visually mimic a tornado when orographic lift creates rotating columns that twist through cloud layers.
Fog is simply a very low stratus cloud that has subsided to ground level, reducing visibility to less than 1 km; above 1 km visibility it's called mist.
Cirrus clouds often form along high-altitude jet streams and can produce virga—precipitation that evaporates before reaching the ground.
Cirrostratus clouds create halos around the Sun and Moon by refracting light through ice crystals.
Cumulonimbus clouds can produce thunderstorms, lightning, hail, heavy rain, flash floods, downbursts, and tornadoes—all from the same cloud type.
Low clouds have a stronger cooling effect because they're bright and reflective, while high thin clouds cause warming because they trap outgoing radiation.
Stratocumulus clouds form when limited convection meets a temperature inversion layer that caps vertical development.
Heinrich events during ice ages caused massive icebergs to be released into the North Atlantic, changing ocean circulation and global climate patterns.
The Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse 300 million years ago was caused by climate change that devastated tropical rainforests across Europe and America.
The Azolla Event 49 million years ago—800,000 years of arctic fern blooms—reversed global warming by pulling CO2 from the atmosphere.
The Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum 55 million years ago was terminated by flourishing marine phytoplankton that absorbed atmospheric CO2.
During the supercontinent Pangaea, climate modeling suggests that the landmass was conducive to establishing megamonsoon circulation patterns.
CERN's CLOUD experiment showed that cosmic rays are too weak to significantly influence climate through cloud formation, debunking a popular alternative theory.
Half the 2021 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for discovering how climate noise becomes climate signal through ocean inertia effects.
Nuclear winter theory predicts that soot from nuclear war could block enough sunlight to cause sharp temperature drops for several years.
The formation of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, enabled by continental drift creating a gap around Antarctica, keeps warm waters away from the continent.
Tree ring analysis for climate study wasn't solidly established as a science until the 1960s, despite earlier pioneering work.
Relative humidity is decreasing over land even as absolute humidity increases, because land is warming faster than the ocean.
The combined change in all sea ice cover between 1992 and 2018 created a warming effect equivalent to 10% of all human greenhouse gas emissions.
Anthropogenic climate change alone cannot cause a runaway greenhouse effect like on Venus—the Planck response creates a strong stabilizing effect.
Ice-albedo feedback strength peaks around 2100 under high warming scenarios and declines afterwards because most easily melted ice will already be gone.
Permafrost thaw produces both CO2 and methane in ways that are difficult to model, creating significant uncertainty in carbon cycle predictions.
The Clausius-Clapeyron relation predicts approximately 7% more water vapor in the atmosphere for every 1°C of warming.
Melt ponds on sea ice have lower albedo than white ice, creating a local feedback that accelerates melting.
Low clouds cool the Earth while high clouds warm it; climate change is expected to shift cloud distributions in ways that reduce overall cooling.
Tropical cyclones mix ocean layers, inserting heat deeper into the water with potential effects on global climate patterns.
The Fujiwhara effect causes two nearby tropical cyclones to orbit each other, with the weaker one often dissipating.
Hurricanes rotate counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere due to the Coriolis effect.
The Northwest Pacific sees tropical cyclones year-round, making it the most active basin with an average of 26 storms per year.
Ten warning centers worldwide are designated by the World Meteorological Organization to issue tropical cyclone advisories for their regions.
Kelvin waves regulate tropical cyclone development by influencing the westerlies, with formation reduced 3 days before the wave crest and increased 3 days after.
Rossby waves can help form new tropical cyclones by transferring energy from existing mature storms.
The African easterly jet contributes to cyclone formation in the Atlantic by creating areas of atmospheric instability.
La Niña years increase hurricane landfalls in China and intensify storms in the Philippines by shifting the subtropical ridge westward.
El Niño reduces Atlantic hurricane activity through increased vertical wind shear across the basin.
Hurricanes can generate lightning, mainly in rainbands up to 160 km from the center, though they produce less lightning than typical thunderstorms.
The dielectric strength of moist air is about 3 MV/m—when the local electric field exceeds this, lightning discharge occurs.
Volcanic eruptions produce lightning through charge separation in ash clouds—the same basic process as thunderstorm lightning.
Dust storms and forest fires can both produce lightning through charge separation in suspended particles.
Thundersnow—lightning during a snowstorm—occurs when warm moist air rises through cold air, usually in winter storms.
Ice crystals become positively charged and graupel becomes negatively charged when they collide in thunderclouds—this charge separation drives lightning.
Fulminology is the scientific study of lightning, derived from the Latin 'fulmen' meaning lightning bolt.
Lightning releases energy between 200 megajoules and 7 gigajoules—enough to power a 100-watt light bulb for several months.
The 'stepped leader' of lightning establishes the channel over hundreds of milliseconds, while the actual discharge takes only a few dozen microseconds.
Step potentials from lightning—voltage differences along the ground surface—kill more people in groups than direct strikes.
The 'skin effect' causes lightning current to travel on the surface of conductors, which is why multi-stranded wires work better for lightning protection.
In the tropics, where the freezing level is higher, only 10% of lightning is cloud-to-ground; at Norway's latitude, 50% is cloud-to-ground.
A 'megaflash' is defined by the American Meteorological Society as a continuous lightning flash with a horizontal path of approximately 100 km or greater.
One hypothesis for lightning initiation involves cosmic rays accelerating electrons to create 'runaway breakdown' that ionizes air and starts the leader.
Positive lightning tends to occur more frequently in winter storms, during intense tornadoes, and in the dissipation stage of thunderstorms.
Positive lightning is responsible for triggering sprites in the upper atmosphere and can propagate through clear air as 'bolts from the blue.'
Heat lightning is simply lightning from a distant thunderstorm that can be seen but not heard because the thunder dissipates over distance.
Dry lightning occurs when rain from a thunderstorm evaporates before reaching the ground—it's a major cause of wildfires.
St. Elmo's fire and ball lightning are distinct phenomena, though they are often mistakenly identified as each other.
The coldest average monthly temperature in the Northern Hemisphere was -56.7°C (-70.1°F) at Verkhoyansk, Russia, in January 1892.
The lowest temperature in the Northern Hemisphere was -69.6°C (-93.3°F) on the Greenland Ice Sheet on December 22, 1991.
The greatest 24-hour temperature increase was 57°C (102.6°F) at Loma, Montana, on January 15, 1972, rising from -48°C to 9°C.
Jean-Pierre Perraudin, a carpenter and chamois hunter, was the first to propose in 1815 that glaciers once extended much farther, inspiring the ice age theory.
The ice age theory was initially rejected—geologist Jean de Charpentier called Perraudin's glacier hypothesis 'so extraordinary and even so extravagant.'
Louis Agassiz omitted mention of Karl Friedrich Schimper, who coined 'ice age' and helped develop the theory, due to personal quarrels.
The ice age theory wasn't fully accepted internationally until the late 1870s, after James Croll published 'Climate and Time' explaining the causes.
Ice ages require specific continental positions: a continent at a pole, a nearly land-locked polar sea, or a supercontinent covering most of the equator.
Evidence suggests brief glaciation periods occurred even during the warm Early Cretaceous, with ice sheets possibly extending to the Iberian Peninsula.
The evolution of land plants at the start of the Devonian period increased oxygen and reduced CO2, leading to the late Paleozoic ice house.
Ice sheets may have briefly returned to Antarctica just before the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction event that killed the dinosaurs.
Glacial periods follow 40,000-year and 100,000-year cycles due to Milankovitch cycles—periodic changes in Earth's orbit and axial tilt.
The 2004 Nature paper suggests the current interglacial may be most analogous to one that lasted 28,000 years.
